tn.text: The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:isa:63:11|63:11]])
Isaiah introduces this desire for Yahweh's presence in their past history with a strong exclamation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: if you had split open the heavens
tn.text: If Yahweh had shown himself very dramatically by tearing open the sky. The words "split open" refer to ripping a piece of cloth apart. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
The mountains would have trembled as in an earthquake. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: as when fire kindles the brushwood, or the fire makes water boil
tn.text: This possibly emphasizes how easily God's presence would have caused the mountains and the people to tremble. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
The people of Israel continues speaking to Yahweh.
"eye" refers to seeing something. AT: "nor has anyone seen" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.
This is an idiom that means "remember." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.

tn.ref: and all our righteous deeds are like a menstrual rag
tn.text: A "menstrual rag" is a cloth that a woman uses during the time of month when she bleeds from her womb. This means all their attempts to please God fail. This sentence was meant to be shocking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: We have all withered like leaves
tn.text: Isaiah compares the people of Israel to leaves that dry up when dead. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: our iniquities, like the wind, carry us away
tn.text: This means their sins, as a community, are the reason for their failure. Isaiah compares the iniquities to the wind as the force for their suffering Yahweh's punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: you have hidden your face from us
tn.text: This means God gave up on his people and let them suffer. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.

tn.ref: we are the clay. You are our potter; and we all are the work of your hand
tn.text: This means God created the people of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to remembering the past. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Isaiah asks Yahweh to pay attention to their situation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The people of Israel continue speaking to Yahweh.

tn.ref: Your holy cities have become a wilderness
tn.text: This emphasizes that the cities have been destroyed and no one lives there.

tn.ref: Our holy and beautiful temple, where our fathers praised you, has been destroyed by fire
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "The enemy has destroyed our holy and beautiful temple, where our fathers praised you, by fire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: How can you still hold back, Yahweh? How can you remain silent and continue to humiliate us?
tn.text: They use questions to express their frustration because God has not yet come to help them. AT: "Please do not hold back, Yahweh! Please do not remain silent and continue to humiliate us!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
